awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Global solar irradiance forecasting with flexible prediction time horizons
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a generalizable approach for accurate and scalable prediction of solar light (irradiance) based on freely available satellite cloud images. High penetration of renewable energy is essential for decarbonizing the grid and decelerating anthropogenic climate change. The intermittency of renewable energy, however, is currently a hurdle in its cost-effective integration, which is only partially solved by improved energy storage. Improving the accuracy of solar irradiance forecasts is a vital step towards effective utilization and integration of solar energy since it allows utilities and electricity market operators to make informed decisions for scheduling reserve capacity and designing efficient bidding strategies in the wholesale power markets. Moreover, it allows the strategic value of solar deployment to be assessed at various scales. The proposed technology can benefit utilities, energy market operators, and policymakers by allowing them to make informed decisions in regulating, planning, and operating the grid.

This I-Corps project harnesses the power of big data and the latest developments in deep learning to develop a generalizable Convolutional Global Horizontal Irradiance prediction model.  Specifically, the model leverages convolutional neural networks and cloud imagery to accurately predict solar irradiance and has been validated across several U.S. sites.  Rigorous posterior analyses have been conducted to study the model's variable skill as a function of prediction time horizon and cloud cover and to demonstrate the benefits of incorporating mesoscale atmospheric dynamics for enhanced prediction performance. The technology addresses key fundamental gaps in state-of-the-art solar irradiance forecasting technologies as it combines the benefits of physics-based solar irradiance prediction models (with no need for in-situ measurement) with the accuracy and scalability of statistical models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This funding opportunity allowed us to conduct customer discovery for our technology related to solar irradiance forecasting. We conducted 112 customer interviews with electric utilities, independent system operators, regional transmission operators, solar tech manufacturers, forecasters as well as regulators. The I-CORPS program allowed us to clearly formulate the value propostion of our technology, identify the customer segment, validate/invalidate our key hypotheses, and assess the market potential of our technology. 

Specifically, the current pain point for independent system operators, regional transmission organizations and some utilities is ensuring that solar generation matches prior commitments. Leveraging our technology can reduce the gap in megawatts between electricity supply and demand. We identified grid operators and forecast scientists at regional transmission operators/transmission system operators (RTOs/TSO) as well as energy consultants as our key customer segments. It is important to note that we realized a much keener interest by RTO/TSO in providing predictions during heat extremes which led us to conduct additional R&D to extend our prototype's capabilities. On the other hand, our initial hypothesis that weather forecast companies, investment companies, residential customers, and tech companies owning solar farms would be interested in our product was invalidated by our interviews. 

Moreover, during the discovery phase and based on the great feedback from our interviewees, we further extended our technology by combining it with a time-series deep learning model and a probabilistic forecasting deep learning model  to predict not only solar irradiance but also prediction uncertainties. Quantitative and qualitative analyses of our extended model revealed that the technology can accurately predict a point solar irradiance of a given region [our model outperform the existing pubic/commercial models by 10-15%], and also return reasonable probability distribution that has uncertainty information.
